parse.title: Endorsements in the Greek bailout referendum, 2015

text.*:
The examples and perspective in this article deal primarily with the United Kingdom and do not represent a worldwide view of the subject. You may improve this article, discuss the issue on the talk page, or create a new article, as appropriate. (July 2015) (Learn how and when to remove this template message)

During the Greek bailout referendum, 2015 a number of newspapers, individuals, politicians, political parties and organisations in Greece, Europe and internationally issued endorsements for either 'NO' to accepting the Troika bailout terms or 'YES'.

Contents

  • 1 Politicians
    • 1.1 No
    • 1.2 Yes
  • 2 Individuals
    • 2.1 No
    • 2.2 Yes
  • 3 Political parties
    • 3.1 No
    • 3.2 Yes
    • 3.3 Others
  • 4 Newspapers
    • 4.1 No
  • 5 Organisations
    • 5.1 No
    • 5.2 Yes
  • 6 References

Politicians[edit]

No[edit]

  • Jeremy Corbyn, British Labour Party politician and leadership candidate[1]
  • Tom Copley, Labour Party member of the London Assembly[2]
  • Diane Abbott, British Labour Party MP and candidate for Mayor of London[3][4]
  • Bernie Sanders, U.S. Senator and candidate for President of the United States[5]

Yes[edit]

  • Giorgos Kaminis, mayor of Athens[6]
  • Yiannis Boutaris, mayor of Thessaloniki
  • Andy Burnham, British Labour Party politician and leadership candidate[7]
  • Jean-Claude Juncker, President of the European Commission[8]
  • Martin Schulz, German MEP and President of the European Parliament[9]

Individuals[edit]

No[edit]

  • Thomas Piketty, French economist[10]
  • George Galloway, British politician and broadcaster[11][12]
  • Paul Krugman, American Nobel Prize winning economist[13]
  • Owen Jones, British socialist newspaper columnist, political activist and writer[14][15]
  • Joseph Stiglitz, American Nobel Prize winning economist[10]
  • Jeffrey Sachs, economist[10]
  • Steve Keen, British-based economist and author[16]
  • Max Keiser, British-based broadcaster, financial commentator and film maker[17]
  • Kim Dotcom, German-Finnish internet entrepreneur, businessperson and political activist[18]
  • Harry Leslie Smith, British writer, political activist and former RAF fighter in World War II[19]
  • Tariq Ali, British writer, film-maker and journalist

Yes[edit]

  • Christopher Pissarides, Cypriot-British economist[10]
  • Ieronymos II of Athens, Archbishop of Athens, primate of the Church of Greece[20]

Political parties[edit]

This is the official list of endorsements by political parties as it was released by the Ministry of Interior:[21][22]

No[edit]

  • Syriza, governing party of Greece
  • Independent Greeks, governing party of Greece
  • Golden Dawn, parliamentary opposition party in Greece
  • Anticapitalist Left Cooperation for the Overthrow, minor party
  • Agricultural Party of Greece, minor party
  • United Popular Front, minor party
  • Popular Unions of Bipartisan Social Groups, minor party

Yes[edit]

  • New Democracy (Greece), opposition party
  • To Potami, opposition party
  • Panhellenic Socialist Movement, opposition party
  • Democratic Left, minor party
  • Movement of Democratic Socialists (KIDISO), minor party
  • Recreate Greece, minor party

Others[edit]

Apart from the parties listed above, the Communist Party of Greece called for the use of a write-in ballot option, "even if they say that it is a spoiled ballot".[23] The Communist Party of Greece (Marxist-Leninist) and the Marxist-Leninist Communist Party of Greece ran a joint campaign for a boycott of the vote.[24] The Organization for the Reconstruction of the Communist Party of Greece also called for a boycott of the vote, calling it a 'fascist farce'.[25]

Newspapers[edit]

No[edit]

  • The News Line, British Trotskyist daily newspaper[26]
  • Morning Star, British socialist daily newspaper[27]

Organisations[edit]

No[edit]

  • Greece Solidarity Campaign, British-based solidarity organisation[28]
  • People's Assembly Against Austerity, British political campaign

Yes[edit]

  • Technical Chamber of Greece
  • Athens Bar Association
  • Panhellenic Federation of Teaching and Research Staff
  • Central Union of Greek Municipalities
  • Greek Regions Union
